sections.content: Prompt engineering is the skill of communicating effectively with AI to get desired outputs. The quality of AI output is directly proportional to prompt quality. A vague prompt ('help me with marketing') gets vague output. A specific, well-structured prompt gets excellent output. Learning to write effective prompts is the highest-leverage skill for AI productivity.

sections.title: Anatomy of a Good Prompt
items: Role: Tell AI what perspective to take ('You are an expert marketer')
Task: Clearly state what you want done ('Create 5 email subject lines')
Context: Provide relevant background ('for B2B SaaS product launch')
Format: Specify output structure ('as numbered list')
Constraints: Define limitations ('under 50 characters each')
Tone: Indicate desired style ('professional but friendly')

sections.content: Example transformation. Weak: 'Write about marketing.' Strong: 'You are a marketing consultant. Write a 500-word guide on email marketing for small businesses. Include 5 actionable tips. Use conversational tone with examples. Format as: intro paragraph, 5 numbered tips with explanations, conclusion.' Notice the difference in clarity and specificity.

sections.title: Key Prompting Principles
items: Be specific: 'Write engaging social media post' → 'Write 280-character Twitter post about X, include hook, problem, solution, CTA'
Provide examples: Show AI what you want ('like this: [example]')
Set constraints: Length, tone, format, what to avoid
Iterate: First output is starting point, refine with follow-ups
Use delimiters: Separate sections with ###, ---, or ``` for clarity
Step-by-step: For complex tasks, break into sequential steps

sections.title: Common Prompt Patterns
items: Task + Context: 'Summarize [document] for [audience] focusing on [aspects]'
Role-playing: 'Act as [expert]. Analyze [situation] and recommend [solution]'
Format specification: 'Create [content] as [format: table/list/script]'
Iteration: 'Make previous response [more/less] [attribute]'
Comparison: 'Compare [A] and [B] on [criteria], show in table'
Examples-based: 'Here are examples: [examples]. Create similar for [topic]'

sections.content: Prompt templates save time. Create templates for repeated tasks with [variables] to fill in. Example: 'Write [length] [content type] about [topic] for [audience] in [tone] style, including [elements].' Save your best prompts in a swipe file for reuse and refinement.

sections.title: Prompt Mistakes
items: Too vague: 'Help me' without specifics
No context: Assuming AI knows your situation
No format: Not specifying structure of output
One-shot: Not iterating when output isn't quite right
Too complex: Asking for too many things in one prompt
No constraints: Leaving too much open to interpretation
Expecting mindreading: Not spelling out what you want

quiz.question: What are the key components of a good prompt?
options: Role, task, context, format, constraints, and tone
quiz.explanation: Good prompts include role, clear task, context, desired format, constraints, and tone. This specificity generates quality outputs.

quiz.question: What should you do if first AI output isn't perfect?
options: Iterate and refine with follow-up prompts
quiz.explanation: Always iterate. First output is a starting point. Refine with follow-up prompts: 'Make this shorter/longer/more X'.

sections.content: Context is everything. AI doesn't know your industry, audience, goals, or constraints unless you tell it. The more relevant context you provide, the better the output. Think of AI as a brilliant but uninformed assistant: extremely capable but knows nothing about your specific situation. Your job is providing context efficiently.

sections.title: Types of Context to Provide
items: Audience: Who will consume this? (executives, customers, beginners, experts)
Purpose: What's the goal? (inform, persuade, entertain, educate)
Tone: How should it sound? (formal, casual, technical, friendly)
Background: What does AI need to know? (industry, product, situation)
Constraints: What are the limits? (length, budget, timeline, resources)
Examples: Show what you want or similar good examples

sections.content: Example with context: 'Write product description for wireless earbuds. Target audience: fitness enthusiasts age 25-40. Emphasize: sweat-proof, long battery life, secure fit. Tone: energetic and motivating. Length: 100 words. Avoid: technical jargon.' This context shapes output precisely.

sections.title: Clarity Techniques
items: One task per prompt: Don't ask for 10 things at once
Numbered steps: For multi-step requests, number the steps
Delimiters: Use ### or ``` to separate sections clearly
Explicit negatives: State what you DON'T want ('Don't include X')
Specific metrics: 'About 500 words' not 'medium length'
Examples: Show examples of desired output style

sections.title: Before/After Examples
items: Before: 'Write email about meeting' → After: 'Write professional email confirming Tuesday 2pm sales meeting, mention agenda items: Q4 goals, new product launch, team expansion. Tone: enthusiastic but professional. Length: ~150 words.'
Before: 'Help with code' → After: 'Debug this Python function [paste code]. It should sort list but returns error. Explain the bug and provide corrected version with comments.'

Before: 'Create social post' → After: 'Write LinkedIn post announcing our new AI tool for marketers. Hook: surprising stat about time spent on copywriting. Include: problem, solution (our tool), benefit, CTA. 150-200 words. Professional yet conversational tone.'

sections.content: The context-quality curve: More context generally means better output, but there's diminishing returns. The first 2-3 context elements provide 80% of improvement. Don't write essays—focus on most relevant context. With practice, you'll identify which context matters most for different tasks.

sections.title: Maintaining Context in Conversations
items: Reference previous: 'Based on the outline you created...'
Build incrementally: Start broad, narrow with follow-ups
Refresh when needed: Restate key context if conversation is long
New chat for new topic: Don't mix unrelated topics in one chat
Summarize progress: 'So far we've discussed X, now let's...'
Context persistence: AI remembers the conversation, leverage this

quiz.question: Why is context important in prompts?
options: AI knows nothing about your situation unless you provide context
quiz.explanation: AI has no knowledge of your specific situation, audience, goals, or constraints. Providing context enables relevant, useful outputs.

quiz.question: What should you do for multi-step requests?
options: Write them as one long sentence
quiz.explanation: Number steps clearly for multi-step requests. This ensures AI addresses each component and makes output easier to verify.

sections.content: Prompt frameworks are structured approaches for consistently getting quality outputs. Instead of reinventing prompts each time, use proven frameworks as starting points. These frameworks have been tested across thousands of use cases. Learn 3-5 frameworks that cover your common needs, then adapt them to specific situations.

sections.title: RACE Framework
items: Role: Define AI's perspective ('You are a senior financial analyst')
Action: Specify exact task ('Analyze this company's financial statements')
Context: Provide background ('For potential investment decision, focus on profitability and growth')
Example: Show desired output format or style ('Similar to: [example]')
Usage: Best for expert-level work requiring specific perspective

sections.title: CRAFT Framework
items: Context: Situation and background
Role: Who is the AI
Action: What to do
Format: Output structure
Target: Who is the audience
Example: 'Context: Launching new SaaS product. Role: Marketing strategist. Action: Create launch email sequence. Format: 3 emails, subject lines and body. Target: B2B decision-makers.'

sections.title: Chain of Thought (CoT)
items: Concept: Ask AI to think step-by-step
Trigger phrase: 'Let's think step-by-step' or 'Show your reasoning'
Usage: Complex problems, math, logic, analysis
Example: 'Calculate ROI for this investment. Show your calculations step-by-step.'
Benefit: More accurate results, ability to verify reasoning
When to use: Any task requiring logical steps or calculations

sections.content: Tree of Thoughts framework for complex decisions: 'Generate 3 different approaches to [problem]. For each approach: 1) Explain the strategy, 2) List pros and cons, 3) Predict likely outcome. Then recommend best approach with reasoning.' This forces systematic analysis of alternatives.

sections.title: Few-Shot Prompting
items: Concept: Provide 2-3 examples of desired output
Structure: 'Here are examples: [Example 1], [Example 2], [Example 3]. Now create similar for [your case].'
Usage: When output style is important and hard to describe
Example: Show 3 examples of social media posts in your brand voice, ask for more
Benefit: AI learns pattern from examples
Quality: Examples matter more than instructions sometimes

sections.title: Persona Prompting
items: Concept: AI assumes specific persona with expertise
Format: 'You are [detailed persona]. Your background: [relevant experience]. Your task: [action].'

Example: 'You are a Harvard Business School professor who has taught strategy for 20 years. You're known for practical, actionable advice. Analyze this business model and provide 5 strategic recommendations.'
Benefit: Taps into training data associated with that persona
Usage: Expert analysis, creative work, specialized domains

sections.title: Framework Selection Guide
items: RACE/CRAFT: General purpose, most situations
Chain of Thought: Math, logic, analysis, problem-solving
Few-Shot: Style matching, pattern replication
Persona: Expert analysis, specialized knowledge
Tree of Thoughts: Complex decisions, multiple approaches
Mix and match: Combine frameworks as needed

quiz.question: What is the Chain of Thought technique?
options: Asking AI to show step-by-step reasoning
quiz.explanation: Chain of Thought asks AI to show step-by-step reasoning ('Let's think step-by-step'), improving accuracy on complex problems.

quiz.question: When should you use few-shot prompting?
options: When output style is important and you have good examples
quiz.explanation: Few-shot prompting (providing 2-3 examples) works best when output style matters and is easier to show than describe.

sections.content: Perfect outputs rarely come from first prompts. Iteration—refining through follow-up prompts—is where excellence happens. Think of AI conversation as sculpting: first prompt creates rough shape, follow-ups refine details. Master iterators get 10x better results than people who accept first output. Learn to quickly identify what's wrong and how to fix it.

sections.title: Iteration Strategies
items: Incremental refinement: 'Make this more [specific, concise, detailed, technical]'
Partial regeneration: 'Rewrite the introduction to be more engaging'
Alternative approaches: 'Generate 3 different versions focusing on different angles'
Add/remove elements: 'Add section about X' or 'Remove the part about Y'
Tone adjustment: 'Make this more formal/casual/technical/accessible'
Format changes: 'Convert to bullet points / numbered list / table'

sections.content: Iteration example: Initial prompt generates 80% good article but introduction is weak and conclusion is missing. Follow-ups: 1) 'Rewrite introduction with stronger hook', 2) 'Add conclusion summarizing key points and call-to-action', 3) 'Make section 2 more concise'. Three quick follow-ups transform good to excellent.

sections.title: Common Iteration Prompts
items: Length: 'Make this shorter/longer', 'Expand section X', 'Cut by 30%'
Tone: 'More professional/casual/technical', 'Less jargon', 'More engaging'
Clarity: 'Simplify this', 'Explain like I'm 12', 'Add examples'
Structure: 'Reorganize for better flow', 'Move X before Y'
Quality: 'Make stronger', 'More specific', 'More persuasive'
Alternatives: 'Give me 5 different versions', 'Try different approach'

sections.title: Diagnostic Questions
items: When output is off: 'What exactly is wrong?' (tone, length, focus, structure)
Identify gap: 'What would make this excellent vs. just good?'
Missing elements: 'Does this have everything I need?'
Audience fit: 'Would my target audience find this valuable?'
Clarity: 'Is this clear without prior context?'
Actionability: 'Can someone actually use this?'

sections.content: The conversation approach: Treat AI like colleague you're collaborating with. First output is draft. You review, provide feedback, iterate together. This mindset shift—from 'AI vending machine' to 'AI collaborator'—unlocks far better results. Don't settle for first output when two follow-ups get you to excellent.

sections.title: Efficient Iteration
items: Batch feedback: Give multiple pieces of feedback in one prompt
Be specific: 'Make shorter' → 'Reduce to 300 words, cutting redundancy'
Reference prior: 'In your previous response, change X to Y'
Save good versions: Copy good outputs before requesting changes
Know when to stop: Perfect is enemy of done, 90% is often enough
Start fresh if needed: Sometimes easier to start over than fix bad draft

quiz.question: What should you do with AI's first output?
options: Review and refine with follow-up prompts
quiz.explanation: First outputs are drafts. Review and refine with follow-up prompts to achieve excellence. Iteration is where quality happens.

quiz.question: How should you think about working with AI?
options: As a vending machine that should be perfect first try
As a collaboration where you iterate together
As something that never needs refinement
quiz.explanation: Think of AI as a collaborator. First output is a draft you iterate on together through conversation. This mindset unlocks better results.

sections.content: Building a personal prompt library accelerates your workflow. Every time you create an effective prompt, save it. Over time, you'll have templates for common tasks, proven frameworks for your specific needs, and examples to learn from. This compounds: the more you save, the more efficient you become. Your prompt library becomes your AI superpower.

sections.title: What to Save
items: Prompts that worked well: Especially those requiring iteration to perfect
Frameworks you use repeatedly: Your go-to templates
Domain-specific prompts: Industry or role-specific best prompts
Complex multi-step prompts: Those that took time to develop
Examples of excellent outputs: To reference for quality
Mistakes and fixes: What didn't work and why

sections.content: Organization system: Create categories (Writing, Analysis, Code, Learning, etc.), name prompts descriptively ('LinkedIn_post_template', 'Code_debugging_framework'), add notes about when to use each. Simple text file works, but dedicated tools (Notion, Obsidian, prompt management apps) offer better organization.

sections.title: Template Structure
items: Use variables: Replace specific details with [BRACKETS] for easy customization
Example: 'Write [LENGTH] [CONTENT_TYPE] about [TOPIC] for [AUDIENCE] in [TONE] tone, including [ELEMENTS].'
Document variations: Save different versions for different needs
Add usage notes: When to use, what to customize, example outputs
Version prompts: Track improvements over time
Share with team: Organizational prompt libraries ensure consistency

sections.title: Quick-Access Setup
items: Text expander: Keyboard shortcuts paste common prompts
Browser bookmarks: Organize by category for quick access
Notion/Obsidian: Searchable prompt database
Custom GPTs: Create specialized ChatGPT versions for repeated workflows
Spreadsheet: Simple categorized library with descriptions
Mobile access: Access prompts from phone for on-the-go use

sections.content: Continuous improvement: Review your library monthly. Which prompts do you use most? Which need updating? What new use cases have emerged? This iterative improvement of your prompt library compounds. After a year, you'll have battle-tested templates that generate excellent outputs in seconds.

sections.title: Starter Prompt Categories
items: Writing: Emails, articles, social posts, editing, summarizing
Analysis: Data analysis, research, comparison, evaluation
Creative: Brainstorming, ideation, naming, storytelling
Learning: Explanations, study guides, practice problems, tutoring
Professional: Meeting prep, presentations, reports, documentation
Technical: Coding, debugging, documentation, technical writing
Personal: Planning, decision-making, goal-setting, reflection

quiz.question: What should you save in your prompt library?
options: Prompts that worked well and complex ones you developed
quiz.explanation: Save prompts that worked well, complex ones you developed, domain-specific templates, and frameworks you use repeatedly.

quiz.question: How should you structure prompt templates?
options: Write them very specifically for one use
quiz.explanation: Use [VARIABLE] brackets in templates for easy customization. This makes prompts reusable across similar situations.
